titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Frederick Charles Barghoorn Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Elizabeth Pauk

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday December 8, 2018 at 10:57

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The bulk of the material is from the 1960s and early 1970s, and includes correspondence, departmental and organizational files, research files, and publications. There is little mention of Barghoorn's arrest by the Soviet government in 1963, except for a brief summary of the incident in a letter to Pat Briggs dated November 10, 1965.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research, with the exception of restricted files relating to faculty searches and student recommendations. These records will be open January 1, 2060.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to Yale University for unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Frederick Charles Barghoorn Papers (MS 1676). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The papers are arranged in three series: I. Yale University Files, 1953-1979, II. Professional Files, 1957-1988, III. Subject Files, 1939-1988.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Frederick Charles Barghoorn was born in New York City in 1911. He received his undergraduate degree from Amherst College in 1934 and his doctorate in history from Harvard in 1941. In the 1940s, Barghoorn served in the Division of East European Affairs in the State Department and in the press section of the U.S. Embassy in Moscow. From 1949 to 1951, he headed a federal project interviewing Soviet defectors to analyze their government and society. From 1947 until his retirement in 1980, Barghoorn was a professor in Yale's political science department. He also taught at the University of Chicago and Columbia University. In 1963, Soviet officials jailed Barghoorn in Moscow on espionage charges and released him only under pressure from President John F. Kennedy. Frederick Barghoorn died in Woodbridge, Connecticut, in 1991.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The bulk of the material is from the 1960s and early 1970s, and includes correspondence, departmental and organizational files, research files, and publications. There is little mention of Barghoorn's arrest by the Soviet government in 1963, except for a brief summary of the incident in a letter to Pat Briggs dated November 10, 1965.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Yale University Files (0.5 linear feet) are arranged alphabetically and relate to Yale's Political Science, and Russian and East European Studies departments. The files concern departmental and university business, and include correspondence, minutes of meetings, reports, and memoranda. The files also include Barghoorn's syllabi, reading lists, and examinations for the classes he taught at Yale. Restricted material relating to faculty searches and student recommendations is listed at the end of the inventory.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: See: Restricted Files, Box 8, Folders 1-8. Material will be open January 1, 2060.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Department chair; mostly outgoing correspondence, Barghoorn to Kaufman.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Department chair; memos to the faculty and correspondence with Barghoorn.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: See:Restricted Files, Box 8, Folders 9-13. Material will be open January 1, 2060.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Barghoorn's Professional Files (1.5 linear feet) are arranged alphabetically and include correspondence; materials on grants and funding agencies; various professional organizations and conferences files; and writings, including book reviews and book chapters. The correspondence is divided into several chronological sections. Within each section letters are arranged alphabetically by the last name of Barghoorn's correspondent. There is also a folder of the correspondence between Barghoorn and his former student, Ellen Mickiewicz. The bulk of the correspondence consists of outgoing letters from Barghoorn, chiefly to professional colleagues in academia and government, discussing his and others' work in Soviet studies. There is little mention of his arrest by the Soviet government in 1963, except for a brief summary of the incident in a letter to Pat Briggs dated 1965 November 10. Other letters concern collaborative projects, funding opportunities, and departmental and university matters. A few items mention student unrest at Yale in the spring of 1970.

Grants and funding files contain correspondence, proposals, and application materials. Professional organizations and conferences files include correspondence, programs, and drafts of papers. Barghoorn's writings are comprised of book reviews and chapters for Robert Dahl's Regimes and Oppositions and Wendell Bell and Walter E. Freeman's Ethnicity and Nation-building .

odd.head: General
odd.p: Materials are arranged alphabetically within each date span.

did.unittitle: American Association for the Advancement of Slavic Studies
Conference on Dissent in the Soviet Union, McMaster Studies
International Committee for Soviet and East European Studies, Garmisch Conference

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Barghoorn's Subject Files (1.5 linear feet) are mostly from the 1940s and 1950s and primarily concern the history, politics, and cultural life of the Soviet Union and its republics. There are both English and Russian-language articles, clippings, publications, and Barghoorn's handwritten and typed notes. Many of the items have been annotated by Barghoorn and others.

did.unittitle: Nationalities and representation in the Presidium, C. C. and other control agencies
